Legal_Issue: Whether the Registrar erred in finding Quicklaw had a 'family' of trademarks and requiring Intuit to negate QUICKTAX's distinctiveness
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trademark Opposition Board decision
Evidence_Assessment: Quicklaw provided evidence of use of QUICKTAX since 1988 and other QUICK marks; Intuit failed to sufficiently challenge or prove prior use
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Intuit) to show lack of distinctiveness or prior rights
Credibility_Factor: Registrar found Quicklaw's evidence credible and sufficient
Legal_Rule: Trademark distinctiveness is judged as of the opposition commencement date; family of marks doctrine applies if consistent use and reputation established
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied by Federal Court
Procedural_Issue: Deference to Registrar's expertise in trademark matters
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of distinctiveness, prior use by Intuit
Decision_Maker: Registrar of Trademarks, affirmed by Federal Court
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process was fair and within statutory framework
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of QUICKTAX since 1988, existence of other QUICK marks forming a family
Legal_Framework: Canadian trademark law, including concept of 'family of marks'
Applicant_Challenge: Intuit challenged Quicklawâ€™s application for QUICKTAX
Legal_Rule_Source: Trade-marks Act, case law on family of marks
Defendant_Response: Intuit opposed registration, claiming lack of distinctiveness and prior use
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence of use, trademark registry records
Outcome: Quicklaw retains rights to QUICKTAX trademark
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial review
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Allegation that QUICKTAX lacks distinctiveness due to generic nature and prior use by Intuit
Applicable_Process: Trademark opposition proceeding under Section 38 of the Trade-marks Act
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in Registrar's assessment
Pending_Relief_or_Application: Application for registration of QUICKTAX by Quicklaw
Governing_Rule: Distinctiveness evaluated at opposition date; family of marks can support distinctiveness
